I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the request of the Government of the People's Republic of China (PRC) during the 
country programming mission in December 2012, technical assistance (TA) for strengthening 
management capacity of technical and vocational education and training (TVET) in Hunan was 
included in the Asian Development Bank's (ADB) 2013 nonlending program. ADB fielded a TA 
reconnaissance mission in June 2013, during which agreement was reached with the Hunan 
Education  Department  (HED)  on  the  TA's  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  costs  and  financing, 
implementation  arrangements,  and  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services.  The 
design and monitoring framework (DMF) is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Strengthening  human  resources  by  developing  TVET  is  a  key  priority  of  the 
government’s Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015. In 2010, with approval of the National Long-
Term Strategy on Education, 2010–2020, the central government identified the expansion of 
TVET as the main way to build a more skilled workforce. A major challenge in this effort is to 
reform the TVET system so that it aligns more closely with the country’s economic and social 
development goals. 
 
3.  Hunan is a less-developed province in the south-central part of the PRC. It has a 
population  of  72  million.  The  province’s  economy  is  being  transformed  by  the  central 
government’s    policy  of  economic  and  geographic  rebalancing,  which  seeks  to  expand 
economic growth from the PRC’s coastal regions toward its less-developed inland provinces 
and autonomous regions. This effort has led to Hunan’s emergence as an important industrial 
base that requires a large labor force with a wide range of skills. In 2011, demand for such 
skilled workers exceeded supply in Hunan, with manufacturing generating the greatest need. 
The province needs to make its labor force more competitive and to foster skills-intensive 
growth that is driven by innovation. What is lacking in Hunan, however, is the capacity needed 
within the provincial government, its agencies, and the TVET system to fully implement the 
PRC’s National Long-Term Strategy on Education.  
 
4.  To develop a modern TVET system, the provincial government, the HED, and the TVET 
institutions and stakeholders need to be able to assess, assure, and certify the quality of the 
TVET being delivered in the province and to use these assessments to make improvements and 
align the training and education provided with industry needs. The institutional capacity needed 
for quality assurance is currently lacking, and guidelines for monitoring key indicators have to be 
developed at the provincial level to measure the performance and promote the accountability of 
TVET institutions. Hunan pioneered skills assessment in the PRC in 2010 but needs to enhance 
its assessment methods and disseminate knowledge about skills testing across the province.  
 
5.  Coastal  provinces  such  as  Guangdong  and  Jiangsu  and  the  centrally  administered 
municipality of Chongqing in the southwestern region have done more to reform TVET since the 
Eleventh Five-Year Plan was announced in 2006 than the less-developed provinces in the 
PRC’s western and central regions, where progress has been moderate. Ningbo City in Jiangsu 
Province has developed and implemented the country’s first regulatory framework for industry–
school  partnerships  by  offering  tax  incentives  to  enterprises  that  participate  in  TVET, 
establishing a board of governors to improve interagency coordination in TVET, setting up a 
training  fund,  and  expanding  on-the-job  training.  Chongqing  has  spearheaded  reforms  to

2   
strengthen quality improvement in TVET. Potential exists to replicate these good practices in 
Hunan and elsewhere within the framework of a PRC government initiative to twin eastern and 
western provinces to facilitate the sharing of experience, lessons, and best practices in TVET 
development.  
 
6.  The TA  aims to  strengthen the TVET  management  capacity  in  Hunan,  address  its 
current weaknesses, and work toward achieving the goals of the provincial Twelfth Five-Year 
Plan.  
 
7.  The  TA  will  (i)  develop  recommendations  for  strengthening  quality  improvement 
mechanisms at the TVET institution level; (ii) make recommendations for improving skills testing 
and certification, including the development of assessment standards in the priority fields of 
study;  (iii)  conduct  policy  research  and  present  recommendations  for  monitoring  key 
performance indicators in TVET; and (iv) develop technical guidelines for establishing an east–
west partnership in TVET between Hunan and an eastern province, including assessing and 
defining  policy,  operational,  institutional,  and  technical  aspects  of  such  a  partnership. 
Documents will be reviewed, detailed consultations with relevant stakeholders conducted, field 
visits undertaken, and case studies examined to produce the TA outputs. 
 
8.  The TA will complement ADB's TVET demonstration project in Hunan by ensuring that 
there will be strong management capacity building activities at a senior management level in the 
HED, TVET institutions, and relevant industry advisory groups as the demonstration undertaking 
goes forward.2 The TA will gather and consolidate information about national developments in 
TVET in the PRC, and the TA findings will be disseminated at the provincial and national levels 
through workshops and policy briefs. This capacity building through information dissemination 
for senior management officials will be essential for strengthening ownership of the initiatives 
under the demonstration project to improve TVET–industry linkages and match TVET programs 
with market demand. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be strengthened capacity of the government and other stakeholders for 
managing the TVET system in Hunan Province. The outcome of the TA will be improved TVET 
management in Hunan through consideration by HED of the recommendations and guidelines 
prepared by the TA. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The outcome will be achieved through five outputs:  
 
(i)  a review of the institution-level TVET quality assurance system in Hunan; 
(ii)  technical  guidelines  for  strengthening  an  institution-level  TVET  quality 
improvement framework; 
(iii)  recommendations for improving skills testing and certification in the priority fields 
of study, including development of assessment standards;

(iv)  technical guidelines for an east–west partnership in TVET; and 
(v)  recommendations on how to monitor key performance indicators in TVET. 
 
11.  The TA will be implemented in three phases over 18 months. During the 2 months of 
phase 1, the consulting firm engaged under the TA will review, analyze, and report on the 
present status of TVET policies and practices in the province, particularly regarding quality 
assurance, testing, and certification. Outlines of technical guidelines will then be prepared for           
(i) making improvements at the institution-level in the quality of skills testing and certification,                 
(ii) monitoring of key performance indicators, and (iii) establishing an east–west partnership. 
The outlines will be disseminated to stakeholders. Activities under phase 1 will include 
 
(i)  reviewing the current TVET quality assurance practices in Hunan and in the PRC, 
including identification of (a) institutional constraints and opportunities, and (b) 
national best practice in TVET quality assurance mechanisms; 
(ii)  reviewing  the  current  skills  testing  and  certification  frameworks  in  Hunan, 
including assessment methodologies in the priority fields of study in Hunan; 
(iii)  reviewing the current practice of monitoring key performance indicators in Hunan; 
(iv)  preparing outlines of technical guidelines for the selected items; and 
(v)  organizing a workshop for relevant stakeholders at the end of phase 1 to discuss 
the outline technical guidelines.  
 
12.  During phase 2 (9 months), the outlines produced in phase 1 will be developed into draft 
technical guidelines that will be pilot tested and validated in two or three TVET institutions. In 
parallel,  international  and  national  study  tours  to  selected  ADB  member  countries  will  be 
organized for five or six government staff members to familiarize them with best practices in 
TVET management and governance for their future guidance.  The phase 2 activities will 
include 
 
(i)  the drafting of technical guidelines for the institution-level quality improvement 
system,  an  east–west  partnership,  and  the  monitoring  of  key  performance 
indicators (based on the outlines developed in phase 1); 
(ii)  the development of a draft quality improvement manual for institution-level TVET 
quality improvement; 
(iii)  the identification of two or three TVET institutions where the draft guidelines for 
the institution-level quality improvement system can be pilot tested and validated; 
(iv)  the  development  and  presentation  of  recommendations  for  further  improving 
skills testing and certification;  
(v)  the  organization  of  a  multistakeholder  workshop  to  present  and  discuss  the 
findings of the field validation and the  resulting policy recommendations, and to 
finalize the draft technical guidelines; and 
(vi)  identification  of  the  partner  institutions  for  the  study  tours,  development  of 
rational  criteria  for  selecting  up  to  five  or  six  government  staff  members  to 
participate in the study tours, and organization and implementation of the tours. 
 
13.  Phase 3 will take 7 months and involve the finalization of the draft technical guidelines to 
be submitted to the HED for the quality improvement system, the skills testing and certification, 
the monitoring of key performance indicators, and the east–west partnership. A knowledge 
dissemination strategy will be developed and implemented, a provincial workshop to share 
findings and experiences will be conducted, and a policy note on best practices will be prepared 
as a knowledge product.

4   
14.  Achievement  of  the  TA  objectives  assumes  that  (i)  the  national  and  provincial 
governments will continue to make TVET development a priority, (ii) high-level authorities within 
the HED will regard and support the TA as a priority project, (iii) the provincial authorities will 
provide timely guidance during TA implementation, (iv) the HED will agree to and implement the 
TA recommendations effectively, and (v) the local authorities and pilot TVET institutions will 
cooperate fully in pilot testing activities. 
 
15.  The major risks to successful implementation are (i) inadequate or delayed provision of 
necessary  data  by  key  respondents,  (ii)  delayed  submission  of  required  information  by 
counterpart individuals and institutions, (iii) inadequate performance of the consultants, (iv) poor 
coordination between the HED and other relevant agencies, (v) inadequate involvement of 
industry representatives, and (vi) ineffective dissemination of the TA findings and outputs by the 
HED. The HED has agreed to provide all necessary data in a timely manner, as well as 
adequate counterpart support. Close coordination between the consultants, the HED, and ADB, 
in consultation with the project steering committee (PSC), will further mitigate the risks. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $400,000, of which $350,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The HED will provide  
counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  office  accommodation,  remuneration  and  per  diem  of 
counterpart  staff,  materials,  maps,  data,  and  documents  required  for  the  TA,  domestic 
transportation (city transport), miscellaneous administration and support costs (including the 
cost  of  utilities  for  the  use  of  the  consultants),  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  cost 
estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The executing agency for the TA will be the HED, which is responsible for developing 
provincial policies and guidelines for TVET development. The HED is also the implementing 
agency for the ADB-funded lending project for TVET demonstration in Hunan (footnote 2). This 
will ensure that the outputs of the TA will complement the  loan project. The PSC will be 
established by the HED and be chaired by the director of the TVET division of the HED. PSC 
members  will  include  representatives  from  the  relevant  divisions  of  the  HED,  the  Hunan 
Department of Science and Technology, and the Hunan Department of Human Resources and 
Social Security. 
 
18.  The TA will finance consulting services, workshops, training, and field work costs. The 
consultants will provide expertise in (i) TVET quality assurance, (ii) skills testing and certification, 
(iii) TVET performance monitoring and accountability, and (iv) east–west partnership in the PRC. 
A total of 26 person-months of consulting services will be required (7 international and 19 
national).  The  HED  will  authorize  and  convene  the  workshops  and  training,  which  the 
consultants will organize and administer. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are 
in Appendix 3. The consultants will be engaged by ADB through a firm in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time) under the quality- 
and cost-based selection method, based on the quality of the proposal (80%) and the cost (20%) 
of the services to be provided and using the simplified technical proposal procedure. 
 
19.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The HED has

5 
experience in implementing TA projects financed by international development partners and has 
an adequate accounting records-keeping system. TA disbursement will be handled by ADB. 
 
20.  It is envisaged that the TA implementation will commence on or about 1 February 2014 
and be completed 18 months thereafter, on or about 31 July 2015. The TA will be monitored 
through the use of project specific indicators and targets. These will include indicators to monitor 
the timely implementation of the TA. Policy dialogue will be maintained with the government, 
and  ADB  will  take  up  project-specific  issues  with  government  counterparts  during  review 
missions. Technical milestones will be monitored by inception, midterm, and final reports to be 
prepared  by  the  consultants.  Milestones  related  to  TA  implementation  will  be  monitored 
regularly by the consultant team leader and the ADB task manager. 
 
21.  Good  practices  and  lessons  learned  from  this  TA  will  be  disseminated  through 
continuous policy dialogue, TA workshops, and knowledge products. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People's Republic of China for Technical and Vocational Education and 
Training Management Capacity Building in Hunan, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consultants will have expertise in (i) technical and vocational education and training 
(TVET) quality assurance, (ii) skills testing and certification, (iii) TVET performance monitoring 
and accountability, and (iv) east–west partnership in the PRC. The indicative terms of reference 
for the experts are in paras. 2–7. 
 
A.  Technical and Vocational Education and Training Quality Assurance Expert and 
Team Leader (international, 4.0 person-months) 
 
2.  The  expert  should  have  academic  background  related  to  institutional  planning  and 
development and TVET policy making and management, 10 years of work experience in TVET 
quality assurance, and management of TVET system improvement projects. The expert should 
be  experienced  in  designing  technical  guidelines  related  to  quality  assurance.  Previous 
experience as a team leader in projects financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) or in 
other internationally funded projects will be an advantage. The expert will be responsible for the 
overall coordination and supervision of the project activities and outputs and will, among other 
responsibilities, perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Prepare a detailed work plan for the TA, ensure that the team's work progresses 
according to schedule, including timely submission of the TA inception, interim, 
final reports, and other relevant outputs to a quality acceptable to the Hunan 
Education Department (HED) and ADB. 
(ii)  Liaise and coordinate effectively with the HED, TVET institutions, local expert 
institutions, and other relevant government agencies involved in the TA. 
(iii)  Carry out an assessment of international and national best practices for TVET 
quality  assurance,  including  policy  and  regulatory  frameworks,  technical 
standards, and approaches. 
(iv)  Review  the  policy  and  regulatory framework  and  current  practices  in  quality 
assurance in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
(v)  Assess the potential and constraints of quality assurance in the PRC, particularly 
under  the  TVET  project  funded  by  the  Australian  Agency  for  International 
Development in the municipality of Chongqing.  
(vi)  Prepare  a  technical  note  with  recommendations  on  institution-level  quality 
improvement for the HED, including a chapter on international and national best 
practices in quality assurance. 
(vii)  Develop technical guidelines for institution-level quality improvement and pilot 
test and validate the technical guidelines in two or three TVET institutions (to be 
selected by the HED). 
(viii)  Support the government, particularly the HED, in efforts to disseminate the TA 
findings to the Ministry of Education and other national, provincial, and municipal 
agencies. 
(ix)  In close collaboration with the HED, organize and administer multistakeholder 
workshops and present the draft technical guidelines and recommendations to 
strengthen Hunan’s TVET management and quality improvement systems.  
(x)  Assist the HED in identifying the destination for an international study tour and 
help organize this tour. 
(xi)  Develop a capacity-building plan to strengthen quality improvement for the HED 
officials responsible for TVET development and presidents and vice-presidents of 
Hunan’s TVET institutions.  
(xii)  Organize  and  administer  the TA  inception, midterm  review,  and  final review 
workshops.

(xiii)  Support the HED in organizing and conducting a final workshop to present and 
discuss the TA findings and recommendations.  
 
B.  Quality Assurance Expert and Deputy Team Leader (national, 9.0 person-months) 
 
3.  This  expert  should  have  academic  background  related  to  institutional  planning  and 
development and TVET policy-making and management. The expert should have more than  8 
years of work experience in TVET policy and planning and quality assurance, managed TVET 
projects, and have experience in implementing national projects. The expert will be responsible 
for day-to-day liaison with the HED and national government agencies supporting related works. 
Among other responsibilities, the expert will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Foster close collaboration between the international and national consultants and 
coordinate  effectively  with  the  executing  agency,  other  related  government 
agencies, and ADB. 
(ii)  Assist the team leader in preparing a detailed work plan for the TA.   
(iii)  Carry out an assessment of international and national best practices for TVET 
quality  assurance,  including  policy  and  regulatory  frameworks,  technical 
standards, and approaches. 
(iv)  Review the policy and regulatory framework and current practices in Hunan in 
quality assurance. 
(v)  Assess the potential and constraints of quality assurance in the PRC, particularly 
under  the  TVET  project  funded  by  the  Australian  Agency  for  International 
Development in Chongqing. 
(vi)  Prepare  a  technical  note  with  recommendations  on  institution-level  quality 
improvement for the HED.  
(vii)  Develop technical guidelines for institution-level quality improvement and pilot 
test and validate the technical guidelines in two or three TVET institutions (to be 
selected by HED). 
(viii)  Participate and give presentations in provincial and national workshops under the 
TA project. 
(xiv)  Assist the team leader in (a) preparing TA inception, interim, and final reports, 
including revising  chapters or sections as necessary to ensure that TA outputs 
are adequate in scope and  quality; (b) supporting the government and the HED 
in particular in their efforts to disseminate the study’s findings to the relevant 
national,  provincial,  and  municipal  agencies;  and  (c)  organizing  a  multi-
stakeholder  workshop  and  presenting  the  draft  technical  guidelines  and 
recommendations  to  strengthen  Hunan’s  TVET  management  and  quality 
assurance systems. 
(ix)  Organize, participate in, and give presentations at TA workshops.  
 
C.  Technical and Vocational Education and Training Performance and Accountability 
Management  Experts  (1  international,  1.5  person-months;  1  national,  4.0  person-
months) 
 
4.  The international expert should have an academic background related to institutional 
performance assessment and TVET policy making and management and more than 10 years of 
work experience in TVET management, monitoring and evaluation. The national expert should 
have the same academic background as the international expert and more than 5 years of work 
experience in TVET management and monitoring and evaluation. Among other responsibilities, 
the experts will perform the following tasks:

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(i)  Carry out an assessment of international and national best practices for TVET 
performance management (focusing on monitoring key performance indicators), 
including  policy  and  regulatory  frameworks,  technical  standards,  and 
approaches.  They  will  prepare  a  report  on  international  and  national  best 
practices in monitoring key performance indicators for the HED. 
(ii)  Review Hunan’s policy and regulatory framework and current practices in TVET 
performance monitoring. 
(iii)  Review and assess existing data sources at the national, provincial, and school 
levels for measuring performance of TVET institutions in Hunan.  
(iv)  Coordinate and lead the development of provincial-level technical guidelines for 
developing, testing, and monitoring key performance indicators.  
(v)  Prepare technical guidelines on monitoring key performance indicators for the 
HED. 
(vi)  Prepare  a  comprehensive  best-practice  policy  note  on  TVET  performance 
monitoring in the PRC—an ADB knowledge product that is to be submitted to 
ADB and the HED for dissemination. 
(vii)  Participate and give presentations in the provincial and national workshops under 
the TA project. 
 
D.   Skills  Testing  and  Certification  Experts  (1  international,  1.5  person-months;  2 
national, 3.0 person-months) 
 
5.  The  international  expert  should  have  academic  background  related  to  TVET  skills 
development and assessment and labor practice and more than 10 years of work experience in 
skills  testing  and  assessment  in  TVET.  The  two  national  experts  should  have  the  same 
academic background as the international expert and work experience in skills teaching and 
research in technical programs in TVET. At least one of the national experts should have up to 
date  experience  of  working  in  a  TVET  institution  in  Hunan  Province  on  skills  testing 
development  and  management.  Among  other  responsibilities,  the  experts  will  perform  the 
following tasks: 
 
(i)  Carry out an assessment of international and national best practice for skills 
testing and certification, including policy and regulatory frameworks, technical 
standards, and approaches. 
(ii)  Review the current student assessment methods in the priority fields of study 
used by TVET schools and colleges in Hunan and other provinces and areas 
(e.g.,  the  experience  of  Chongqing),  including  feedback  from  administration, 
trainers, students, and industry representatives. 
(iii)  Review  the  policy  on  assessment  and  reporting  in  TVET  and  provide 
recommendations and changes to upgrade the policy to meet the requirements 
of a competency-based assessment (CBA) system. 
(iv)  Recommend improvements to increase the relevance and quality of TVET in the 
priority fields of study, including the development of CBA methods and tools. 
(v)  Provide suggestions to plan the transition from traditional examinations to CBA 
methods. 
(vi)  Review  and  provide  recommendations  for  improving  the  existing  student 
assessment instrument in Hunan in the priority fields of study. 
(vii)  Include recommendations for quality assurance approaches (e.g., verification of 
assessment) to ensure the validity and reliability of the CBA system. 
(viii)  Prepare technical guidelines and recommendations for improving skills testing 
and certification.

Appendix 3  13 
E.  Provincial Partnerships Advisor (national, 3.0 person-months) 
 
6.  The  advisor  should  have  an  academic  background  related  to  TVET-industry 
management and cooperation and at least 5 years of experience in public–private and east–
west partnerships in the context of the PRC. The advisor will provide direction on east–west 
partnerships that have been successful in the PRC and lay out the principles for a TVET 
partnership between Hunan and an eastern province (e.g., Jiangsu Province). Specifically, the 
advisor will perform the following tasks: 
  
(i)  Review the literature and reports produced by the National Development and 
Reform  Commission,  ADB,  and  other  relevant  institutions  on  east–west 
partnership operations and results in the PRC. From this review, the advisor will 
elicit the most relevant and recent lessons for successful and sustainable east–
west partnerships and summarize the results in terms of lessons learned. 
(ii)  Assist the HED select a twinning east–west partnership province for Hunan.  
(iii)  Recommend  principles  for  east–west  agreements  and  engagement  in  TVET 
between  Hunan  and  the  selected  province,  focusing  particularly  on  TVET 
management and quality assurance. 
(iv)  Engage in, and document and synthesize the findings of, all brainstorming and 
peer  reviews  for  east–west  partnership,  incorporating  all  findings  and 
recommendations. 
(v)  Organize a study visit for Hunan TVET officials to the twinning province (e.g., 
Jiangsu). 
(vi)  Provide  a  final  set  of  recommendations  and  technical  guidelines  on  the 
partnership model.  
 
F.  Reporting Requirements 
 
7.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report within 2 months 
of mobilization, (ii) an interim report submitted 8 months after the TA commences, (iii) a draft 
final report 16 months after the TA commences, and (iv) the revised final report submitted 1 
month  after  receiving  comments  on  the  draft  final  report  from  the  HED  and  ADB.  The 
consultants will submit all reports in the English and Chinese languages—six copies each in 
Chinese and English to the HED, and three copies of the English version to ADB, including one 
electronic copy in a CD-ROM. The knowledge product will be submitted to ADB and the HED for 
dissemination at the national and provincial levels.
